Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the parent needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: A patient is at a routine check-up and has general questions about their health.
Story: I was in the supermarket with my seven-year-old son, trying to finish our shopping before my afternoon clinic. He darted between aisles, giggling, ignoring my quiet reminders to stay close and behave. I felt the eyes of other shoppers on us, expecting me to step in, to teach him respect and discipline. My phone buzzed—my next patient, Mrs. Lee, was early and anxious, waiting for reassurance about her recent test results. As a doctor, I knew she needed my full attention, my calm and empathetic presence. But as a parent, I couldn’t ignore my son’s behavior or the lesson he needed right now. My mind raced, torn between the duty to guide my child and the responsibility to my patient. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding more than I could give at that moment.
